elements.content: A series of s mediated by a long and flexible amine 1,2-bis­(3-aminopropylamino)­ethane (BAPEN), [Zn3(HEDP)2­(H2BAPEN)­(H2O)]·5H2O (1), (H4BAPEN)0.5·[Zn3­(HEDP)2­(H2O)]·2H2O (2), and (H4BAPEN)0.5·[Zn3­(HEDP)2]·H2O (3) (HEDP = 1-hydroxyethylidenediphosphonate, CH3C­(OH)­(PO3)2), were successfully assembled, showing diverse structures with different dimensions. Compound 1 displays an infinite Zn-HEDP chain that is decorated by chelating BAPEN. Compound 2 possesses an anionic Zn-HEDP layer structure with the protonated BAPEN as a charge balancer. Compound 3 features a 3D Zn-HEDP network with protonated BAPEN as the template. The structural diversity for 1–3 from 1D to 2D and 3D was modulated by BAPEN in the assembly process (coordination role for 1 and template role for 2 and 3) together with the different reaction conditions. The photoluminescence properties of compounds 1–3 are investigated. The results show that the solids 1–3 exhibit intense blue fluorescence at ambient temperature under UV light irradiation. Moreover, the proton conduction behavior for compound 3 has been studied.

elements.content:
Three zinc diphosphonates templated by protonated 1,2-bis­(3-aminopropylamino)­ethane were constructed with diverse structures.

Introduction

Metal–organic materials (MOMs), as an emerging class of hybrid solids, have attracted huge interest thanks to their great diversity of structures as well as promising properties. As an important kind of MOM, metal phosphonates have received continuous attention during the past three decades. The integration of metal ions and organophosphonates offers a good chance to generate versatile molecular materials bearing a diverse structure (from isolated clusters to polymeric structure, such as metal–organic frameworks (MOFs)) and appealing properties (adsorption, proton conductivity, optics, catalysis, magnetism, etc.). To fabricate diverse MOMs, the template-directed synthesis approach has been widely adopted and employed. In general, the introduction of organoamine to metal phosphate (or phosphite) greatly promoted the blossoming of synthetic and structural chemistry, which indirectly pushed the exploration of promising structure-related properties and potential applications. Compared with the great achievement in organoamine-directed metal phosphate (or phosphite), metal phosphonate driven by organoamines is still underdeveloped in terms of types and number. In view of the similarity between inorganic phosphorus units (phosphate, PO4 3–; phosphate, HPO3 2–) and organophosphonates (RPO3 2–, R represents the organic moiety), the organoamine-directed assembly is feasible for the production of metal phosphonate. Hitherto, the early works mainly centered on the small molecular organoamines such as aliphatic or heterocyclic amine, whereas the long flexible aliphatic amine and large heterocyclic amine are relatively less investigated.

Introduction

Metal-organic materials (MOMs), as an emerging class of hybrid solids, have attracted huge interest thanks to their great diversity of structures as well as promising properties. As an important kind of MOM, metal phosphonates have received continuous attention during the past three decades. The integration of metal ions and organophosphonates offers a good chance to generate versatile molecular materials bearing a diverse structure (from isolated clusters to polymeric structure, such as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs)) and appealing properties (adsorption, proton conductivity, optics, catalysis, magnetism, etc.). To fabricate diverse MOMs, the template-directed synthesis approach has been widely adopted and employed. In general, the introduction of organoamine to metal phosphate (or phosphite) greatly promoted the blossoming of synthetic and structural chemistry, which indirectly pushed the exploration of promising structure-related properties and potential applications. Compared with the great achievement in organoamine-directed metal phosphate (or phosphite), metal phosphonate driven by organoamines is still underdeveloped in terms of types and number. In view of the similarity between inorganic phosphorus units (phosphate, PO4 3-; phosphate, HPO3 2-) and organophosphonates (RPO3 2-, R represents the organic moiety), the organoamine-directed assembly is feasible for the production of metal phosphonate. Hitherto, the early works mainly centered on the small molecular organoamines such as aliphatic or heterocyclic amine, whereas the long flexible aliphatic amine and large heterocyclic amine are relatively less investigated.

elements.content: In our previous works, we have focused on the investigation of synthetic methodology with respect to novel metal phosphonates directed by various organic amines, including rigid heterocyclic amines (4,4′-bipyridine, 1,3,5-tris­(1-imidazolyl)­benzene, and 2,4,6-tri­(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine) and small flexible organic amines (imidazole and 1,3-propanediamine). In a continuous study on the exploration and acquisition of novel metal phosphonate with both captivating structures and unique properties, we are attempting to select and graft the long and flexible organoamine 1,2-bis­(3-aminopropylamino)­ethane (C8N4H22, BAPEN) to metal-1-hydroxyethylidenediphosphonate system on account of the following concerns: (a) The cheap diphosphonate HEDP with multiple coordination modes is helpful for the manufacture of phosphonate-based MOMs; (b) the zinc­(II) ion, with a flexible coordination number (from 4 to 6 or even higher) and geometric configuration (tetrahedra, trigonal bipyramid, and octahedra), is a promising candidate for the fabrication of phosphate-based MOMs; and (c) the phosphonate-based MOMs possess advantages in seeking a framework structure with high photoluminescence or other properties ().

elements.content: Herein we report three BAPEN-mediated zinc diphosphonates, [Zn3(HEDP)2(H2BAPEN)­(H2O)]·5H2O (1), (H4BAPEN)0.5·[Zn3(HEDP)2(H2O)]·2H2O (2), and (H4BAPEN)0.5·[Zn3(HEDP)2]·H2O (3). Compound 1 has a Zn-HEDP chain structure modified by BAPEN via a chelating intrachain zinc ion. Unlike 1, compound 2 exhibits an anionic Zn-HEDP layer with the protonated BAPEN as a charge balancer. A protonated BAPEN-templated Zn-HEDP frame was constructed for compound 3. The diverse 1D, 2D, and 3D structures for compounds 1–3, respectively, were modulated by the organic amines in the process of assembly (coordination role for 1 and template role for 2 and 3) together with the distinct reaction conditions. The syntheses, structural characterization, photoluminescence, and proton conduction properties for the compounds have been well investigated.

elements.content: All chemicals (analytical grade) were bought and used directly without any purification. A Philips X’Pert-MPD diffractometer with a Cu-target tube was utilized to carry out the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) spectroscopy. Thermogravimetric (TG) measurement was performed on a NETZSCH STA 449 F5 analyzer with the temperature ranging from 30 to 800 °C with N2 as the protective gas. Elemental analysis for CHN data were obtained from a PerkinElmer 240C analyzer. The MAGNA-560 Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer was employed to conduct the IR spectroscopy. Photoluminescence spectra were obtained from an FLS920 spectrophotometer. The proton conduction behavior was studied on a Solartron 1287 electrochemical interface.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All chemicals (analytical grade) were bought and used directly without any purification. A Philips X'Pert-MPD diffractometer with a Cu-target tube was utilized to carry out the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) spectroscopy. Thermogravimetric (TG) measurement was performed on a NETZSCH STA 449 F5 analyzer with the temperature ranging from 30 to 800 °C with N2 as the protective gas. Elemental analysis for CHN data were obtained from a PerkinElmer 240C analyzer. The MAGNA-560 Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer was employed to conduct the IR spectroscopy. Photoluminescence spectra were obtained from an FLS920 spectrophotometer. The proton conduction behavior was studied on a Solartron 1287 electrochemical interface.

elements.content: A mixture of 0.29 g ZnSO4 (1.00 mmol), 0.30 mL of BAPEN (1.64 mmol), 0.28 mL of H4HEDP (1.97 mmol), and 10 mL of H2O was mixed together and put in a Teflon-lined autoclave with volumetric capacity of 20 mL. The content was heated and kept at 145 °C for 4 days, followed by temperature cooling. Colorless sheet crystals could be acquired in a 60% yield on the basis of Zn. elements.content: Data collection for X-ray-quality crystals 1–3 was performed at room temperature on an XtaLAB-mini diffractometer with Mo–Kα radiation. The SHELX-2016 software was utilized to solve and refine the structures of 1–3. The highly disordered water molecules in the first two structures were treated by the “SQUEEZE” procedure in PLATON software suite. Through the TG curves and elemental analysis data, we calculated the final number of the guest molecules. summarizes the detailed data, and Tables S1–S3 list the selected bond distances and bond angles for the structures of 1–3 (CCDC 1890697, 1890696, and 1890695 , respectively).
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Data and Refinement

Data collection for X-ray-quality crystals 1-3 was performed at room temperature on an XtaLAB-mini diffractometer with Mo-Kα radiation. The SHELX-2016 software was utilized to solve and refine the structures of 1-3. The highly disordered water molecules in the first two structures were treated by the "SQUEEZE" procedure in PLATON software suite. Through the TG curves and elemental analysis data, we calculated the final number of the guest molecules.  summarizes the detailed data, and Tables S1-S3 list the selected bond distances and bond angles for the structures of 1-3 (CCDC 1890697, 1890696, and 1890695 , respectively).

Compound 1 belongs to the monoclinic P21 /n space group with an asymmetric unit containing three Zn­(II) ions, two HEDP molecules, one H2BAPEN moiety, and one coordinated and five guest water molecules. Both Zn(1) and Zn(2) centers are four-coordinated and adopt the [ZnO4] tetrahedral coordination geometry (a). For Zn(1), the coordinative O atoms are from water and the −PO3 group of HEDP, whereas the coordinative O atoms for Zn(2) are from the −PO3 group of HEDP. The five-coordinated Zn(3) exhibits a square pyramid [ZnO3N2] geometry, wherein the basal plane is composed of two N atoms from BAPEN ligand (Zn–N 2.140(9)/2.158(7) Å) and two O atoms from an HEDP species, whereas the apical site is occupied by the O atom from another HEDP species. Each HEDP ligand features the η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η0:η0:μ3 mode to link three Zn2+ ions (the first six η represent the coordination modes of two −PO3 groups of HEDP, and the last η represents the coordination mode of the −OH group of HEDP) (Figure S1). The bond lengths between Zn­(II) and O atoms are 1.912(7) to 2.115(7) Å, and the angles around Zn­(II) ions range from 82.1(3) to 159.7(3)°. The chelating-bridging HEDP ligand bonds with Zn atoms to form a zinc-diphosphonate chain as supramolecular building units, which are further linked by a [ZnO3N2] square pyramid to generate the final double parallel chain (b). Notably, the protonated BAPEN (H2BAPEN) not only acts as chelating ligands to coordinate the Zn(3) atoms but also serves as counterions to balance the negative charge of the chain. The chelating H2BAPEN ligands feature relatively long flexible noncoordinative units, which hinder the further extension of the chain (c,d). Intermolecular forces such as a hydrogen bond (Table S4) between the guest BAPEN and the host extend the 1D chain to a 3D solid-state packed structure.

Results and Discussion

Structural Description of [Zn3(HEDP)2(H2BAPEN)(H2O)]⋅5H2O (1)

Compound 1 belongs to the monoclinic P21 /n space group with an asymmetric unit containing three Zn(II) ions, two HEDP molecules, one H2BAPEN moiety, and one coordinated and five guest water molecules. Both Zn(1) and Zn(2) centers are four-coordinated and adopt the [ZnO4] tetrahedral coordination geometry (a). For Zn(1), the coordinative O atoms are from water and the -PO3 group of HEDP, whereas the coordinative O atoms for Zn(2) are from the -PO3 group of HEDP. The five-coordinated Zn(3) exhibits a square pyramid [ZnO3N2] geometry, wherein the basal plane is composed of two N atoms from BAPEN ligand (Zn-N 2.140(9)/2.158(7) Å) and two O atoms from an HEDP species, whereas the apical site is occupied by the O atom from another HEDP species. Each HEDP ligand features the η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η0:η0:μ3 mode to link three Zn2+ ions (the first six η represent the coordination modes of two -PO3 groups of HEDP, and the last η represents the coordination mode of the -OH group of HEDP) (Figure S1). The bond lengths between Zn(II) and O atoms are 1.912(7) to 2.115(7) Å, and the angles around Zn(II) ions range from 82.1(3) to 159.7(3)°. The chelating-bridging HEDP ligand bonds with Zn atoms to form a zinc-diphosphonate chain as supramolecular building units, which are further linked by a [ZnO3N2] square pyramid to generate the final double parallel chain (b). Notably, the protonated BAPEN (H2BAPEN) not only acts as chelating ligands to coordinate the Zn(3) atoms but also serves as counterions to balance the negative charge of the chain. The chelating H2BAPEN ligands feature relatively long flexible noncoordinative units, which hinder the further extension of the chain (c,d). Intermolecular forces such as a hydrogen bond (Table S4) between the guest BAPEN and the host extend the 1D chain to a 3D solid-state packed structure.

elements.content: It is revealed from the structural analysis that compound 2 belong to a low- symmetrical triclinic crystal system with space group of P1̅. There are three independent Zn­(II) ions, two HEDP molecules, half of one fully protonated BAPEN (H4BAPEN), and one coordinated and two lattice water molecules in the asymmetric unit. As depicted in a, Zn(1) and Zn(2) atoms adopt the four-coordinated mode and locate in the center of the [ZnO4] tetrahedron, whose vertices are defined by four phosphonate O atoms from two independent HEDP molecules. Unlike Zn(1) and Zn(2), Zn(3) adopts a six-coordinated [ZnO6] environment and locates in the center of a distorted octahedron. The equatorial positions are generated with four oxygen atoms from two HEDP molecules, and the axial positions are defined by one O atom from −OH of HEDP as well as one water molecule. The two HEDP ligands exhibit two different bridging modes: One displays the η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η0:η0:μ4 mode to link four Zn2+ ions (Figure S2a); the second one shows the η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:μ5 pattern to connect five Zn2+ ions (Figure S2b). The distances between Zn and O centers are in the scope of 1.903(5) to 2.343(5) Å, whereas the angles are found to be in the range of 76.89(17) to 166.6(2)° around Zn­(II) ions. The chelating-bridging HEDP moieties connect Zn atoms to generate a 2D anionic layer in which two types of rings (four- and eight-membered) exist and are constructed from vertex-sharing of [ZnO6] octahedra and [ZnO4] and [CPO3] tetrahedra (b). To assist the better understanding of this intricate layer, topology analysis is introduced. The two HEDP units could be considered as a four- and five-linked nodes, respectively, whereas for different Zn centers, they could be regarded as three- and four-connected nodes. Thus, on the basis of this simplification, compound 2 can be treated as a new (3,4,5)-connected four-nodal net with stoichiometry (3-c)­(4-c)2(5-c) (c). As illustrated in d, the protonated BAPEN moieties as counterions occupy the spaces between adjacent layers. Moreover, the parallel layers are gathered together through an electrostatic interaction and a hydrogen bond with the guest molecules (Table S5) to construct a 3D supramolecular architecture.

The distances between Zn and O centers are in the scope of 1.903(5) to 2.343(5) Å, whereas the angles are found to be in the range of 76.89(17) to 166.6(2)° around Zn(II) ions. The chelating-bridging HEDP moieties connect Zn atoms to generate a 2D anionic layer in which two types of rings (four- and eight-membered) exist and are constructed from vertex-sharing of [ZnO6] octahedra and [ZnO4] and [CPO3] tetrahedra (b). To assist the better understanding of this intricate layer, topology analysis is introduced. The two HEDP units could be considered as a four- and five-linked nodes, respectively, whereas for different Zn centers, they could be regarded as three- and four-connected nodes. Thus, on the basis of this simplification, compound 2 can be treated as a new (3,4,5)-connected four-nodal net with stoichiometry (3-c)(4-c)2(5-c) (c). As illustrated in d, the protonated BAPEN moieties as counterions occupy the spaces between adjacent layers. Moreover, the parallel layers are gathered together through an electrostatic interaction and a hydrogen bond with the guest molecules (Table S5) to construct a 3D supramolecular architecture.

elements.content: Compound 3 belongs to the monoclinic C2/c space group and presents a 3D framework. The asymmetric unit of 3 contains three Zn­(II) ions, two HEDP molecules, half of one protonated BAPEN, and a guest water molecule. As displayed in a, all Zn centers have a similar coordination geometry and locate in the [ZnO4] tetrahedron, with the coordinative O atoms coming from two different HEDP ligands. The Zn–O distances are from 1.895(4) to 1.988(4) Å, and the angles for O–Zn–O range from 99.64(19) to 125.0(2)°. The HEDP ligands in 3 display the η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η0:μ4 pattern to link four Zn atoms (Figure S3). Two Zn1 metal ions are linked by two HEDP molecules, generating the [Zn2(HEDP)2] dimeric moiety, with the Zn1···Zn1 distance being 4.490(7) Å. Meanwhile, another μ4-bridging HEDP ligand connects the Zn2 and Zn3 atoms with the Zn2···Zn3 distances being 4.704(4) Å, forming a 1D [Zn­(HEDP)] n wave chain. These dimmers and 1D chains are alternatively interlaced by sharing O atoms, generating an intricate 3D framework (b). Notably, a 1D channel with size of 11.936 Å × 8.113 Å is observable along the b axis (Figure S4), where it contains the protonated BAPEN molecules (c). Topology analysis is conducted to comprehend the complicated 3D framework. If the two HEDP units are regarded as four-connected nodes and the Zn centers are viewed as three- and two-connected nodes (two-connected nodes are omitted), then the 3D skeleton of 3 could thus be delineated as a (3,4)-connected net with a (4·5·6·83)­(4·6·8)­(52·6·83)­(52·8) point symbol (d).

The asymmetric unit of 3 contains three Zn(II) ions, two HEDP molecules, half of one protonated BAPEN, and a guest water molecule. The Zn-O distances are from 1.895(4) to 1.988(4) Å, and the angles for O-Zn-O range from 99.64(19) to 125.0(2)°. The HEDP ligands in 3 display the η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η0:μ4 pattern to link four Zn atoms (Figure S3). Two Zn1 metal ions are linked by two HEDP molecules, generating the [Zn2(HEDP)2] dimeric moiety, with the Zn1⋅⋅⋅Zn1 distance being 4.490(7) Å. Meanwhile, another μ4-bridging HEDP ligand connects the Zn2 and Zn3 atoms with the Zn2⋅⋅⋅Zn3 distances being 4.704(4) Å, forming a 1D [Zn(HEDP)] n  wave chain. These dimmers and 1D chains are alternatively interlaced by sharing O atoms, generating an intricate 3D framework (b). Notably, a 1D channel with size of 11.936 Å × 8.113 Å is observable along the b axis (Figure S4), where it contains the protonated BAPEN molecules (c). elements.content: As described above, compounds 1–3 possess quite different architectures. All of them are constructed by sulfates, and thus the influence of the anion can be neglected. Compared with the syntheses and structures of 1–3, it could be indicated that the dosage of structure-directing agents as well as the temperature play remarkable roles in the formation of zinc diphosphonates. Compound 1 shows a 1D double chain constructed from Zn centers, HEDP ligands, and H2BAPEN molecules, in which HEDP displays two kinds of μ3-connection modes. The neighboring Zn···Zn distance separated by μ3-HEDP is 3.903(9) to 6.028(2) Å. To generate different structural motifs, various reaction conditions were employed and adjusted in compounds 2 and 3. When less BAPEN was used at a higher temperature 160 °C, compound 2 with a 2D grid-like network was obtained. In 2, −PO3 groups of HEDP with tetradentate and pentadentate bridging modes link the neighboring Zn centers to generate a 2D inorganic–organic hybrid layer. The uncoordinated HEDP in 2 is doubly protonated to become a cationic structure-directing agent. When decreasing the amount of HEDP in compound 3, as expected, a novel 3D framework was obtained. Each HEDP in 3 adopting a μ4 mode links the adjacent Zn cations to yield two types of building blocks, in which there are two kinds of Zn···Zn distances of 4.490(7) and 4.704(4) Å, respectively. These two kinds of building units are alternatively interweaved with each other, generating the 3D 3,4-connected architecture. Moreover, structural analysis demonstrates that the flexible organic amine plays a critical role in the fabrication of different structures, as the coordination role results in a 1D chain for 1, whereas the template role gives rise to a 2D layer and a 3D network for 2 and 3, respectively. In a word, the structural differences indicate that conformations and coordination modes of organic amine as well as reaction conditions influence the construction of structures with different dimensions for compounds 1–3.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Diversity and Comparison of 1-3 

As described above, compounds 1-3 possess quite different architectures. All of them are constructed by sulfates, and thus the influence of the anion can be neglected. Compared with the syntheses and structures of 1-3, it could be indicated that the dosage of structure-directing agents as well as the temperature play remarkable roles in the formation of zinc diphosphonates. Compound 1 shows a 1D double chain constructed from Zn centers, HEDP ligands, and H2BAPEN molecules, in which HEDP displays two kinds of μ3-connection modes. The neighboring Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance separated by μ3-HEDP is 3.903(9) to 6.028(2) Å. To generate different structural motifs, various reaction conditions were employed and adjusted in compounds 2 and 3. When less BAPEN was used at a higher temperature 160 °C, compound 2 with a 2D grid-like network was obtained. In 2, -PO3 groups of HEDP with tetradentate and pentadentate bridging modes link the neighboring Zn centers to generate a 2D inorganic-organic hybrid layer. The uncoordinated HEDP in 2 is doubly protonated to become a cationic structure-directing agent. When decreasing the amount of HEDP in compound 3, as expected, a novel 3D framework was obtained. Each HEDP in 3 adopting a μ4 mode links the adjacent Zn cations to yield two types of building blocks, in which there are two kinds of Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distances of 4.490(7) and 4.704(4) Å, respectively. These two kinds of building units are alternatively interweaved with each other, generating the 3D 3,4-connected architecture. Moreover, structural analysis demonstrates that the flexible organic amine plays a critical role in the fabrication of different structures, as the coordination role results in a 1D chain for 1, whereas the template role gives rise to a 2D layer and a 3D network for 2 and 3, respectively. In a word, the structural differences indicate that conformations and coordination modes of organic amine as well as reaction conditions influence the construction of structures with different dimensions for compounds 1-3.

elements.content: Distinct from the metal phosphonates directed by the small or rigid heterocyclic amines, such as (HN­(C2H5)3)4[Zn7(L)6]·2H2O, [H2pip]3[Ge­(hedp)2]·14H2O, and [H3TPT]­[Zn3(CH3C­(O)­(PO3)2)­(CH3C­(O)­(PO3)2H)]·(H2O), the long and flexible organoamine (BAPEN)-directed metal diphosphonates are seldom reported despite the fact that some metal phosphates (or phosphites) with BAPEN as the template have been investigated, including [C8N4H26]­[Zn3Cl­(HPO4)3(PO4)], [C8N4H26]­[Ga6F4(PO4)6], and so on. BAPEN contains eight methylene groups, which can generate different bond angles through the rotation of C–C bonds to conform to the space requirement. On the contrary, four amino units of BAPEN can also be deprotonated to coordinate to metal ions or protonated to serve as cationic species. Although the assembly of suitable metal ions with HEDP to fabricate desirable metal diphosphonates has been reported, the structures of compounds 1–3 are different from the reported ones due to the different template. In view of the developmental synthesis strategy, the employment of long and flexible organoamine as a template is an excellent choice for the generation of novel structures and topologies.

BAPEN contains eight methylene groups, which can generate different bond angles through the rotation of C-C bonds to conform to the space requirement. On the contrary, four amino units of BAPEN can also be deprotonated to coordinate to metal ions or protonated to serve as cationic species. Although the assembly of suitable metal ions with HEDP to fabricate desirable metal diphosphonates has been reported, the structures of compounds 1-3 are different from the reported ones due to the different template. In view of the developmental synthesis strategy, the employment of long and flexible organoamine as a template is an excellent choice for the generation of novel structures and topologies.

elements.content: TG measurements for powder samples 1–3 were performed under a N2 atmosphere from 30 to 800 °C. The TG curves for the compounds are displayed in . A weight loss of 9.01% for 1 in the beginning below 130 °C is due to the release of guest water molecules (cal: 10.17%). No obvious weight loss could be observed with temperature of 123–200 °C. A next weight loss of 2.25% is ascribed to the removal of coordinated water molecules (cal: 2.03%) upon further heating to ∼220 °C. A platform from 220 to 300 °C then appears, followed by the collapse of the desolvated framework. Likewise, the release of water molecules (cal: 7.27%) also gives rise to the first weight loss of compound 2 below 135 °C (exp: 6.85%). Further heating to 390 °C leads to the following continuous weight loss of 11.38%, which could be attributed to the removal of protonated H4BAPEN (cal: 11.97%). Then the skeleton starts to collapse. For compound 3, the first weight loss is found to be 2.75% below 120 °C, owing to the removal of lattice water molecules (cal: 2.55%). A long-lived steady plateau occurs from 130 to 380 °C. Upon being further heated, the compound shows continuous multistep weight loss, which may be caused by the removal of protonated BAPEN and the collapse of the framework. In short, compounds 1–3 can be stable up to ca. 300, 390, and 380 °C, respectively. In addition, before property measurements, PXRD experiments were performed to substantiate the phase purity for the bulk samples of compounds 1–3. As presented in Figures S5–S7, the main peaks of the experimental patterns are in accordance with the simulated curves derived from crystallographic data, indicating the samples’ purity.

TG and PXRD Analyses

A weight loss of 9.01% for 1 in the beginning below 130 °C is due to the release of guest water molecules (cal: 10.17%). No obvious weight loss could be observed with temperature of 123-200 °C. A next weight loss of 2.25% is ascribed to the removal of coordinated water molecules (cal: 2.03%) upon further heating to ~220 °C. A platform from 220 to 300 °C then appears, followed by the collapse of the desolvated framework. Likewise, the release of water molecules (cal: 7.27%) also gives rise to the first weight loss of compound 2 below 135 °C (exp: 6.85%). Further heating to 390 °C leads to the following continuous weight loss of 11.38%, which could be attributed to the removal of protonated H4BAPEN (cal: 11.97%). Then the skeleton starts to collapse. For compound 3, the first weight loss is found to be 2.75% below 120 °C, owing to the removal of lattice water molecules (cal: 2.55%). A long-lived steady plateau occurs from 130 to 380 °C. Upon being further heated, the compound shows continuous multistep weight loss, which may be caused by the removal of protonated BAPEN and the collapse of the framework. In short, compounds 1-3 can be stable up to ca. 300, 390, and 380 °C, respectively. In addition, before property measurements, PXRD experiments were performed to substantiate the phase purity for the bulk samples of compounds 1-3. elements.content: Coordination networks based on d10 transition-metal ions are of great importance and have attracted much attention owing to their potential applications when serving as optical function materials. Therefore, the solid-state photoluminescence properties of compounds 1–3 were investigated at ambient temperature (), and the observed spectra were compared with the spectral data of pure H4–HEDP solution. The free diphosphonate molecule exhibits a fluorescence emission band centered at 359 nm upon being excited with UV light (λex = 320 nm). This emission band for diphosphonic acid corresponds to π–π* transitions. Compounds 1–3 display a similar emission behavior, and they can emit blue fluorescence emission bands with maxima at 430 nm for 1, 424 nm for 2, and 427 nm for 3, respectively (λex = 370 nm). Because of the difficulty to oxidize or reduce the electrochemically inert Zn­(II) cation, ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) or metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) can essentially hardly occur. According to the previous studies, these emissions may be attributed to the intraligand emissions, as reported for other zinc diphosphonates. The emission bands of the present compounds have been shown to red-shift compared with the pure ligand because the crystal-packing interactions and the coordination interactions in the solid samples could reduce the loss of energy by radiationless decay of the intraligand. Furthermore, the difference in luminescence intensities of these compounds might be attributed to the diverse coordination environment of metal centers as well as the variation of solid-state crystal packing.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence and Proton Conduction Behavior

Coordination networks based on d10 transition-metal ions are of great importance and have attracted much attention owing to their potential applications when serving as optical function materials. Therefore, the solid-state photoluminescence properties of compounds 1-3 were investigated at ambient temperature (), and the observed spectra were compared with the spectral data of pure H4-HEDP solution. The free diphosphonate molecule exhibits a fluorescence emission band centered at 359 nm upon being excited with UV light (λex = 320 nm). This emission band for diphosphonic acid corresponds to π-π* transitions. Compounds 1-3 display a similar emission behavior, and they can emit blue fluorescence emission bands with maxima at 430 nm for 1, 424 nm for 2, and 427 nm for 3, respectively (λex = 370 nm). Because of the difficulty to oxidize or reduce the electrochemically inert Zn(II) cation, ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) or metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) can essentially hardly occur. According to the previous studies, these emissions may be attributed to the intraligand emissions, as reported for other zinc diphosphonates. The emission bands of the present compounds have been shown to red-shift compared with the pure ligand because the crystal-packing interactions and the coordination interactions in the solid samples could reduce the loss of energy by radiationless decay of the intraligand. Furthermore, the difference in luminescence intensities of these compounds might be attributed to the diverse coordination environment of metal centers as well as the variation of solid-state crystal packing.

elements.content: Inspired by the plentiful hydrogen bonds between the protonated aliphatic amine and guest water molecules as well as the phosphonate oxygen of the Zn-HEDP host (Table S6) in the structure of 3, we further investigated its proton conduction behavior by Nyquist plots. Moreover, the adsorbed water molecules could also be employed to assist the formation of H-bonding chains, with diphosphonate molecules serving as proton-conducting pathways, which may further improve the proton conduction property. Interestingly, the conductivity of sample 3 exhibits humidity dependence. When in an ambient environment at room temperature and under humidity, compound 3 shows a negligible conductivity, which is probably due to the lack of an efficient path for proton transmission. Once the tablets of sample 3 are exposed in a closed chamber to deionized water vapor for 10 h, the conductivity could reach 6.28 × 10–5 S cm–1. As displayed in , the impedance of 3 as a function of temperature was performed by modulating the temperature from 25 to 80 °C under 100% relative humidity. With the temperature being gradually elevated, the conductivity of sample 3 increases smoothly and finally reaches a relatively high value of 1.82 × 10–4 S cm–1 at 80 °C. The temperature-dependent behavior of compound 3 suggests that the Zn-phosphonate solids could provide a promising platform to serve as a novel temperature sensor.

elements.content: By virtue of a long flexible aliphatic amine, three zinc diphosphonates exhibiting different dimensions (from 1D to 3D) were constructed. Compound 1 displays a Zn-HEDP chain structure decorated by chelating BAPEN. Compound 2 possesses an anionic Zn-HEDP layer structure with the protonated BAPEN as the charge balancer and space filling. Compound 3 features a 3D complicate Zn-HEDP network with protonated BAPEN acting as the template. The structure diversities were modulated by the distinct role of BAPEN in the assembly process, as the coordination role generates 1 and the template role is responsible for 2 and 3. The photoluminescence as well as the proton conduction properties of the solids are studied in this work. The construction of compounds 1–3 not only develops the types and numbers of metal organophosphonates but also emphasizes the critical role of long flexible aliphatic amine in the fabrication of novel corresponding products. Further research on the exploration of other metal organophosphonate systems driven by long flexible aliphatic amine, following the goal of the acquisition of novel functional crystalline materials, is underway in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

By virtue of a long flexible aliphatic amine, three zinc diphosphonates exhibiting different dimensions (from 1D to 3D) were constructed. Compound 1 displays a Zn-HEDP chain structure decorated by chelating BAPEN. Compound 2 possesses an anionic Zn-HEDP layer structure with the protonated BAPEN as the charge balancer and space filling. Compound 3 features a 3D complicate Zn-HEDP network with protonated BAPEN acting as the template. The structure diversities were modulated by the distinct role of BAPEN in the assembly process, as the coordination role generates 1 and the template role is responsible for 2 and 3. The photoluminescence as well as the proton conduction properties of the solids are studied in this work. The construction of compounds 1-3 not only develops the types and numbers of metal organophosphonates but also emphasizes the critical role of long flexible aliphatic amine in the fabrication of novel corresponding products. Further research on the exploration of other metal organophosphonate systems driven by long flexible aliphatic amine, following the goal of the acquisition of novel functional crystalline materials, is underway in our laboratory.

A mixture of 0.29 g ZnSO4 (1.00 mmol), 0.30 mL of BAPEN (1.64 mmol), 0.28 mL of H4HEDP (1.97 mmol), and 10 mL of H2O was mixed together and put in a Teflon-lined autoclave with volumetric capacity of 20 mL. The content was heated and kept at 145 °C for 4 days, followed by temperature cooling. Colorless sheet crystals could be acquired in a 60% yield on the basis of Zn. Elemental analysis (EA) (%) calcd for C12H44N4O20P4Zn3 (Mr = 884.61): C, 16.29; H, 5.01; N, 6.33. Found: C, 16.58; H, 5.47; N, 6.13. IR (KBr pellets, cm–1): 3420(s), 2971­(m), 2365­(w), 1632(s), 1546­(m), 1446­(m), 1394­(m), 1096(s), 1046(s), 996­(m), 962­(m), 876­(m), 826­(m), 668­(m), 582(s), 513­(w), 474­(w).

0.29 g ZnSO4 (1.00 mmol), 0.28 mL of BAPEN (1.53 mmol), 0.28 mL of H4HEDP (1.97 mmol), and 10 mL of H2O were mixed in a Teflon-lined autoclave. The mixture was allowed to heat to 160 °C for 2 h and kept for 96 h. After slowly being cooled to 30 °C, the plate-like colorless crystals could be obtained in a 35% yield on the basis of Zn. Preparation of (H4BAPEN)0.5⋅[Zn3(HEDP)2]⋅H2O (3)

A mixture of 0.29 g ZnSO4 (1.00 mmol), 0.20 mL of BAPEN (1.09 mmol), and 0.28 mL of H4HEDP (1.97 mmol) was put in a Teflon-lined autoclave; then, 10 mL of H2O was added. The content was kept at 160 °C for 4 days, followed by temperature cooling. Block colorless crystals were isolated in a 50% yield on the basis of Zn. EA (%) calcd for C8H23N2O15P4Zn3 (Mr = 707.39): C, 13.58; H, 3.28; N, 3.96. Found: C, 13.73; H, 3.62; N, 4.27. IR (KBr pellets, cm-1): 3175(s), 2025(w), 1632(s), 1535(w), 1478(m), 1384(s), 1066(s), 1006(w), 966(w), 1094(s), 966(w), 826(s), 753(w), 680(s), 574(s), 504(w).

cln_elements.content: TG measurements for powder samples 1–3 were performed under a N2 atmosphere from 30 to 800 °C. The TG curves for the compounds are displayed in . A weight loss of 9.01% for 1 in the beginning below 130 °C is due to the release of guest water molecules (cal: 10.17%). No obvious weight loss could be observed with temperature of 123–200 °C. A next weight loss of 2.25% is ascribed to the removal of coordinated water molecules (cal: 2.03%) upon further heating to ∼220 °C. A platform from 220 to 300 °C then appears, followed by the collapse of the desolvated framework. Likewise, the release of water molecules (cal: 7.27%) also gives rise to the first weight loss of compound 2 below 135 °C (exp: 6.85%). Further heating to 390 °C leads to the following continuous weight loss of 11.38%, which could be attributed to the removal of protonated H4BAPEN (cal: 11.97%). Then the skeleton starts to collapse. For compound 3, the first weight loss is found to be 2.75% below 120 °C, owing to the removal of lattice water molecules (cal: 2.55%). A long-lived steady plateau occurs from 130 to 380 °C. Upon being further heated, the compound shows continuous multistep weight loss, which may be caused by the removal of protonated BAPEN and the collapse of the framework. In short, compounds 1–3 can be stable up to ca. 300, 390, and 380 °C, respectively. In addition, before property measurements, PXRD experiments were performed to substantiate the phase purity for the bulk samples of compounds 1–3. As presented in Figures S5–S7, the main peaks of the experimental patterns are in accordance with the simulated curves derived from crystallographic data, indicating the samples’ purity.

TG and PXRD Analyses

TG measurements for powder samples 1-3 were performed under a N2 atmosphere from 30 to 800 °C. The TG curves for the compounds are displayed in . A weight loss of 9.01% for 1 in the beginning below 130 °C is due to the release of guest water molecules (cal: 10.17%). No obvious weight loss could be observed with temperature of 123-200 °C. A next weight loss of 2.25% is ascribed to the removal of coordinated water molecules (cal: 2.03%) upon further heating to ~220 °C. A platform from 220 to 300 °C then appears, followed by the collapse of the desolvated framework. Likewise, the release of water molecules (cal: 7.27%) also gives rise to the first weight loss of compound 2 below 135 °C (exp: 6.85%). Further heating to 390 °C leads to the following continuous weight loss of 11.38%, which could be attributed to the removal of protonated H4BAPEN (cal: 11.97%). Then the skeleton starts to collapse. For compound 3, the first weight loss is found to be 2.75% below 120 °C, owing to the removal of lattice water molecules (cal: 2.55%). A long-lived steady plateau occurs from 130 to 380 °C. Upon being further heated, the compound shows continuous multistep weight loss, which may be caused by the removal of protonated BAPEN and the collapse of the framework. In short, compounds 1-3 can be stable up to ca. 300, 390, and 380 °C, respectively. In addition, before property measurements, PXRD experiments were performed to substantiate the phase purity for the bulk samples of compounds 1-3. As presented in Figures S5-S7, the main peaks of the experimental patterns are in accordance with the simulated curves derived from crystallographic data, indicating the samples' purity.
